executive_summary: The Gas Stations industry has experienced significant revenue volatility over the past five years. The industry is sensitive to trends in oil prices because it largely retails gasoline. A decline in the world price of crude oil because of the COVID-19 pandemic led to a substantial decline in revenue in 2020. The pandemic also contributed to the reduction in total vehicle miles, resulting in lower demand for fuel. In contrast, 2021 and 2022 saw fuel prices skyrocket as pent up demand was unleashed, supply chain challenges and geopolitical developments hampered global oil markets. Overall, industry revenue is expected to increase at a CAGR of 2.5% to $140.5 billion over the five years to 2024, including a 1.1% increase in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatility in the World Price of Crude Oil Significantly Impacted Gas Stations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The volatility of crude oil prices over the past five years has posed considerable challenges for the Gas Stations industry. Volatility has been caused by COVID-19, supply chain disruptions and geopolitical tensions like the Russia-Ukraine war. Because gasoline prices are tied directly to the cost of crude oil, drastic fluctuations in oil prices directly impact the cost of gasoline that stations supply and the final price set for consumers at the pump.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: High oil prices impact on gas stations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High oil prices can both positively and negatively impact gas stations, depending on their ability to respond and adapt. When oil prices rise, gas stations can potentially benefit from higher markup on gasoline, resulting in increased per-gallon profit. However, higher oil prices lead to increased gasoline prices, which can reduce consumer demand as people might cut back on driving or switch to more fuel-efficient modes of transportation.

Along with a growing economy, consumers and businesses have spent steadily on fuel. Vehicle fuel is a relatively nondiscretionary good because most consumers require gasoline to drive on a daily basis. As the number of employees in the United States has continued to increase, more people have driven daily, increasing demand for vehicle fuel. Furthermore, as per capita disposable income has grown, some consumers traded up to premium and diesel fuel, benefiting industry revenue.

Diesel fuel sales have increased due to growth in the transportation sector. Both the Local Freight Trucking industry and Long-Distance Freight Trucking industry have experienced revenue growth over the past five years, driven by increasing demand for trucking from various manufacturers and retailers. Because the sale of diesel fuel represents nearly half of industry revenue, improving sales and increasing diesel fuel prices have helped improve revenue performance.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: An Emphasis on Convenience Has Pushed Gas Stations into Other Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Gas stations have experienced growing competition from operators in the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry. More consumers and truck drivers have turned to retail sites that operate convenience stores on-site due to the access to food, beverages and cigarettes, among other sundries. Items sold in convenience stores are more profitable than gasoline, shielding operators somewhat from rising credit card swipe fees and giving them a competitive edge against stand-alone gas stations.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profitability Trends Have Tracked Movements in the Price of Fuel
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The world price of oil has grown over the past five years, hindering profit growth as gas stations have been unable to trim margins as prices at the pump soared. Credit card swipe fees have also grown as consumers increasingly used debit or credit cards rather than cash to make purchases, leading to higher operating expenses. The industry's low margins have led upstream fuel conglomerates to divest from their retail portfolios.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Expansion Will Support Demand for Fuel
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Gas station revenue will be positively impacted by rising per capita disposable income and an increase in road travel by Americans. Growth in disposable income will enable consumers to purchase higher grades of vehicle fuel, increasing revenue per customer. Furthermore, as more diesel-compatible cars are introduced, consumers are anticipated to opt for these vehicles because of their higher fuel efficiency, increasing demand for diesel fuel. Consumer demand for premium-grade gasoline will grow as consumers purchase an increasing number of luxury cars requiring more expensive fuel.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: As Fuel Prices Temper, Revenue at the Pump Will Slow
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The world price of crude oil will decrease consistently over the next five years, following the extreme increases during the previous period. This will cause the retail price of fuel to also drop. The decrease in fuel prices will depress gas stations' revenue as stations will become more price competitive and have to pass on the lower prices to consumers to attract customers. It should be noted that the timing and nature of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) production quota changes are difficult to forecast, and any changes by the organization can alter oil volumes and prices significantly.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Threat From Electric Cars Will Become Ever More Present
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The trends toward smaller and fuel-efficient cars are forecast to expand. The Energy Information Association expects the total amount of energy used by light-duty vehicles to experience a double-digit decline until 2040. Despite an increase in total vehicle miles, greater fuel efficiency will lower the need for fuel. As hybrid and electronic vehicles become more affordable and more widely available, an increasing number of consumers will purchase these vehicles, further lowering demand for gasoline. Gas stations will need to adopt new strategies to remain competitive in the face of changing consumer preferences. Gas stations will start selling more eco-friendly fuel blends and incorporating electric car charging stations into their operations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: As Competition Rises, More Gas Stations Will Expand Their Menu Offerings
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition from both gas stations that operate convenience stores on-site and gas stations owned and operated by external retailers will rise. According to the National Association of Convenience Stores, consumers are increasingly purchasing gasoline based on convenience and price, rather than brand; in response, gas stations are increasingly offering discounts through loyalty programs for consumers during periods of gas price volatility. Nevertheless, as younger consumers become eligible to drive, more consumers will turn to stores that offer a variety of goods in addition to vehicle fuel. More gas stations will opt for more profitable stations with convenience stores rather than stand-alone fuel stations, precepting an exit from the industry as establishments are reclassified to the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry.

industry_definition: This industry comprises gas stations that retail automotive fuels, offer repair services and sell replacement parts and accessories. Gas stations that operate convenience stores on their premises are included in the Gas Stations with Convenience Stores industry (IBISWorld report 44711).
key_trends: Volatile oil prices have translated to fluctuations at the pump.
However, revenue has expanded as a result of the massive spike in oil prices during the pandemic and geopolitical instability.
More gas stations have added convenience stores because consumers value convenience. While this has stabilized profit margins for establishments, it also reclassifies them out of the industry.
A bevy of rules govern companies that work with fuel sales. Most regulations on gas stations are mandated and monitored at the state level.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This demographic is well-established in their careers, has higher disposable incomes and commonly owns at least one vehicle. They frequently visit gas stations due to commuting, family activities, and leisure travel.

This demographic is well-established in their careers, has higher disposable incomes and commonly owns at least one vehicle. They frequently visit gas stations due to commuting, family activities, and leisure travel.

This demographic is well-established in their careers, has higher disposable incomes and commonly owns at least one vehicle. They frequently visit gas stations due to commuting, family activities, and leisure travel.

This demographic tends to have more disposable income than younger consumers but less than older age groups. Many explore alternatives to individual vehicle use due to environmental concerns and cost-efficiency.

While this segment contributes to gas station revenue, they make up the second-smallest market segment due to having less disposable income, not commuting to jobs, and many being too young to have driver's licenses.
This is the smallest market segment largely because many in this age group have reduced daily commuting needs and travel less post-retirement, leading to less frequent fuel purchases.

products_and_services.product_description: Diesel fuel leads sales of all fuels sold at gas stations primarily because establishments cater to trucking enterprises. Consumers have also slowly turned to diesel-compatible passenger cars for better fuel efficiency.

This segment includes the sale of regular, mid-grade and premium gasoline targeted towards individual consumers for their everyday cars. Regular gasoline is the most popular, followed by mid-grade and then premium.
This segment includes automotive parts, repairs and other auto services like repairs, vehicle rentals and car washes, allowing gas stations to differentiate themselves.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Gas Stations Are Located Along Transport Infrastructure Routes
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Locating in densely populated areas with significant commuting activity is strategic for gas stations to gain greater access to consumers who demand fuel frequently.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The Southeast Has the Second Largest Number of Establishments
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The Southeast region has a large population with limited public transportation options, supporting demand for gas stations. It also has many trucking establishments that require fuel.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The Large Population Supports Demand for Gas Stations in the West Region
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The West region hosts major cities, highways, and tourist destinations, driving consistent fuel needs. However, consumers are increasingly shifting towards electric vehicles.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region of the United States.
The Mid-Atlantic region of the United States.
The New England region of the United States.
The Plains region of the United States.
The Rocky Mountains region of the United States.
The Southeast region of the United States.
The Southwest region of the United States.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The government mandates standards for gas quality as established by the American Society for Testing Materials.
New ethanol blending requirements have forced gas station operators to buy new tanks to accommodate the blended fuel.
Various states that receive money from the government for clean water push gas station operators to use new storage tanks to protect groundwater.
In 1990, federal and state government adopted additional gas standards. These standards require the exclusive marketing of cleaner-burning gas in select markets in an effort to improve air quality.

In large sections of the northeastern United States and in a few areas in Texas and the Midwest, a federal reformulated gas that meets specific requirements contained in the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments must be marketed. Additionally, California has its own clean air standards, which require a more environmentally friendly blend of vehicle fuel.

factors_decreased_barrier: Labor requirements are limited, as gas stations primarily employ part-time workers that demand low wages.

basis_points.basis_description: Gas stations compete heavily on price. Fuel is a homogenous product, so downstream consumers typically seek out the lowest prices, especially when oil prices soar globally.
Competition from gas stations with convenience stores has stiffened because drivers value their convenience.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Gas Stations industry has a low level of market share concentration because of the wide geographic dispersion of these service points.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Moderate Barriers to Entry Encourage New Entrants
concentration_points.concentration_description: Starting a gas station can be a relatively accessible business venture, while initial costs can be quite high, running costs are lower and profit is steady. This encourages many entrepreneurs to enter the industry and participate in competition.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: FUEL PURCHASE REPRESENT MOST SPENDING BY GAS STATIONS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The majority of gas station revenue goes towards purchasing fuel for resale. Fuel prices are volatile and significantly impact a station's operating costs.
Maintenance and upgrades of gas pumps, security systems and other equipment also form a significant part of the station's expenses.
Any additional products sold, like automotive parts also add to station's purchase costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor requirements are limited, as gas stations primarily employ part-time workers that demand low wages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CRUDE OIL PRICES DRIVE REVENUE VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The retail price of gasoline is closely correlated to changes in the world price of crude oil.
Economic conditions have a significant influence on the revenue volatility in the Gas Stations industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DIESEL FUEL IS THE INDUSTRY LEADER
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Diesel fuel leads sales of all fuels sold at gas stations primarily because establishments cater to trucking enterprises.
Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.
Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations.
Many gas stations use automated self-service pumps reducing the need for additional staff and further keeping wage expenses down.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a diversified client base, or are sales heavily dependent on one market (consumers, businesses, government)?
FAQs.answer: Gas station operators primarily retail gas to consumers, yet increasing access to businesses could prove lucrative.

FAQs.question: How do consumer trends influence sales?
FAQs.answer: Consumer trends in the total amount of vehicle miles driven, per capita disposable income and the level of travel all influence industry performance.

FAQs.question: How are you expecting input costs to affect revenue and profitability moving forward?
FAQs.answer: Volatility can influence the ability to effectively price goods, hampering profitability in turn.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand its reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Achieving efficiencies through scale is an effective strategy to lower costs and better compete with other industry participants.

FAQs.question: Has increased merger and acquisition activity among your competitors left you at a disadvantage?
FAQs.answer: Some larger operators have merged with upstream oil producers in order to achieve better market position.

FAQs.question: How does your company use new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: More efficient gas pumps can increase turnover, aiding revenue growth in turn.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: POS systems can automate payments, increase convenience for the consumer and reduce overall labor costs.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently? What costs are associated with these regulations?
FAQs.answer: Changes in operations resulting from regulatory requirements can hamper revenue.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure that it is compliant with the EPA's regulations concerning the storage of hazardous materials?
FAQs.answer: Regulations require gas stations to maintain spill prevention and leak detection equipment in their underground storage tanks.

FAQs.question: How are you expecting profit and revenue to perform moving forward?
FAQs.answer: Severe changes in the price of crude oil can significantly affect an industry operator's ability to pass on costs to consumers.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare with your major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Slow turnover in comparison to major competitors can hamper revenue and result in high operating costs.

FAQs.question: Consumers are increasingly choosing gas stations based on convenience. Where is your establishment located? What competitive advances does your location offer?
FAQs.answer: Gas stations located near high traffic areas benefit from greater visibility and foot traffic.

FAQs.question: What steps has your company taken to ensure that your capital structure is optimized? What risk management strategies have you implemented to ensure your business is able to weather tough business conditions?
FAQs.answer: Gas stations can require large amounts of capital when first starting or when they need to be updated.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? Have you had any issues securing or keeping contracts?
FAQs.answer: Securing fuel and automotive parts at a low cost is crucial to maintaining profitability.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating crude oil prices affect your company? How have volatile crude oil prices impacted your business?
FAQs.answer: Crude oil prices largely determine retail gas prices.

FAQs.question: How can tax credits for energy efficiency affect your business?
FAQs.answer: Technology has been advancing quickly when it comes to transportation and reducing the reliance on fossil fuels.

FAQs.question: How can your company track trends in the number of miles driven? How has the changing number of miles driven affected your business?
FAQs.answer: The total of vehicle miles driven plays a huge role in this industry.
